review_title: Great coworkers but racially biased leadership and low pay
pros: I cannot say enough great things about the majority of the coworkers that I worked with. Many were so supportive and understood the toll of the job. Parties were thrown to celebrate anniversaries and retirements.
cons: People were constantly crying in the bathroom. The salary is quite minimum given the workload with very few opportunities to move up. There were several instances of racial bias and it's clear given all of the leadership team is white. When given opportunities to interview for a promotion, they will give you a small critical reason why you did not get it after years of only positive year end reviews with no real feedback. They end up giving the position to a less qualified white person. When reporting someone making a racist comment to me and laughing, they asked what they wanted me to do about it. Clearly not allies to people of color.

review_title: Fantastic Benefits, Good Pay, Terrible Hours
job_title: Event Manager in New Orleans, LA
pros: Working at Marriott was like working with family. I loved my coworkers, always felt supported and able to voice concerns/complaints/ideas for change. Raises were predictable and fair, benefits were really good, and there were ample opportunities to seek new training. The company also cares deeply about diversity and community outreach, and tried their hardest to keep as many of us employed as they could, for as long as they could, during the pandemic. I would never have left if not for COVID.
cons: Schedule was largely unpredictable in my position, and I typically worked 60 to 70 hour weeks, from 8am to 9 or 10pm, including weekends. Clients were often quite rude, and knew that they could get "freebies" by complaining, even if the complaints weren't valid. Beginning event manager salary is very low for the actual hours one ends up working, but with enough years in the position, earnings are more fair.

review_title: Poor Leadership and Toxic Workplace Culture
pros:
Variety of impressive career experiences and opportunities.

Access to brand related resources and benefits.
 
Globally recognized brand to enhance resume.
cons:
Leadership teams are made up of people who need much more management training and goals to hold them accountable for the success and growth of their teams. 
They should consider leadership term limits to allow a variety of diversity of perspectives, styles and expertise.

Employee/Workforce Surveys need to be truly anonymous, and cover 360 degree feedback, to ensure that the company culture, its leaders and practices are reviewed and adjusted when necessary.

There’s a desperate need for more required training for both leadership and the workforce about unconscious bias, sexual harassment, inclusive workforce practices, and conflict resolution skills. Unfortunately, racism and other forms of discrimination are common at HQ and there is a need for better ways to address conflict to support victims when issues occur. 

The performance review process and path to promotion needs to be spelled out more clearly and be supported by a more equitable set of practices.

The salaries and leave are not competitive. 

Hiring friends and family who do not meet basic requirements is a real problem.

cons: Literally everything you can think of when you think of a nightmare company. Management not caring about work/life balance. Pick and choose when to be strict, no open door policy, HR doesn't help when needed, you need anything as a previous employee (like W2's) they give you a huge run around, and even go as far as to hanging up on you if you call the support number after waiting hours to speak to someone. This is not a joke... this company will use you until they don't need or want you anymore. You can give your entire life to these people and they would say thanks then kick you right out the door. No support from management during shifts or after, and the only way to move up is to brown nose. It's a frustrating company to work for and it doesn't get any better after you quit or get fired.

review_title: Long Hours, High Stress, but Great Opportunity to climb Corporate Ladder
job_title: Marriott Voyager in New Orleans, LA
pros: Leadership training, One on One meetings/coaching, Networking opportunities, lots of opportunities to move up the corporate ladder, OT opportunities always available, Great Benefits (Health, Vision, Dental, PTO, 401K, Room Discounts for Family and Friends), forgiving absentee system (can be late by 7mins everyday and still be "on-time", write up system for tracking absences is separate from regular write ups, and as long as you call at least 1 hr before your shift then the call off is considered excused. ) Also, lots of free lunches and there are regular quarterly managerial outings. LGBTQ+ and Minority positive work environment.
cons: Long hours (mandatory 10 hr shifts), Working most weekends, heavy workload during busy season, relatively low pay, PTO/Day off requests are often denied (first come first serve, associates are able to request days off weekends weeks in advance thus blocking others from getting weekends off for extended periods of time), Working very long stretches based on hotel demands (i.e. 10 days without a day off), no set off days.

review_title: Everyone read this review: HQ experience
pros: Explore rate discount and employees can now gain status on discount rate
cons:
This review is prior to COVID furlough/elimination (this is in no way a response to this as I was not eliminated but chose to leave) but I hear all of this is still going on today and relevant: 
*Senior Management: Leaders are out of touch, don't want to actually do work, and have a tendency to dump work downwards on more junior staff. Those same individuals are the ones who weren't furloughed and/or eliminated. 
*Work/life balance: There is none - the expectation is those that can do get dumped on and get extra work to make up for those that are incompetent
*Career Opportunities: Marriott has a culture of promoting within but then you have people wildly incapable of their positions which lets the entire team down
*Compensation/Benefits: it is way below market rate (I left and got a 30k raise for same level) and annual salary increases even for SP are 2%. Bonus - not sure what that even is there as I never received one. 
*People get promoted not based on their work but based on if there happens to be an empty position - its basically waiting on someone to retire before you can get promoted. 
*Culture/Values: Terrible working culture - I have worked at many companies that had their issues too but never with such passive aggressive behavior and competing politics to accomplish a common goal of improving how a company functions. Its amazing adults can act like such children 
*Benefits: Internal employee processes and technology are so archaic. I was using a laptop that was no longer supported by the company leading projects for integration - its simple - set up your employees for success. 
*They have an attitude that just because they are the biggest they can get away with being wildly incompetent in technology, processes, benefits, and customer experience. Not everyone wants to work there - especially those who are competent and understand what its like outside the company.
*How did they get best place to work 2021 when they laid off most of their workforce? That just doesn't add up - even in the best of times if you lay off/furlough staff you're not getting a positive response. The koolaid isnt that strong.

review_title: If you want your voice to be heard, this is not the place for you
pros: Great experience working for a large fortune 500 company. It is a huge place to work and takes a while to know how to navigate through the different departments and areas but is also a "small world."
cons: Being that it is a "small world", many hiring decisions are based on favoritism. With a company this size, hiring decisions should be based on skillset and qualifications. Those who follow the leader will rise in this organization. This is not a place to question the status-quo or be heard for your contradicting viewpoints, which is often necessary for transformation.

review_title: Great Place to Start Your Career!
job_title: Marketing Specialist in New York, NY
pros:
Worked at Marriott for 3+ years. 2020 was an insane year for the travel industry, and I was overwhelmingly impressed with the way that Marriott handled the pandemic. I felt supported by my boss and team throughout the furlough period, and recently accepted a very generous severance package. Overall a great experience. Additional feedback:
- Very little turnover (common for people to stay 10+ years)
- Opportunity for travel 
- Great discounts on hotels 
- Kind, smart, and well-respected management (i.e. Arne and Tina Edmundson)
- Frequent check-ins with bosses are the norm
- Prioritizes happy hours and team building
- Opportunities for growth/development (i.e. shadowing photoshoots, the company paid for me/allowed me a day off to take a graphic design boot camp class that benefitted me and my team overall)
cons:
- Pay is probably less than industry average 
- Working out of a satellite office (in NY) I often felt disconnected from headquarters
